turns.speaker: LENNY
turns.text: What do you need it for? I don't get you lately.

turns.speaker: EVAN
turns.text: Duly noted. Now I'm gonna ask you for one last favor.

turns.speaker: LENNY
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: EVAN
turns.text: Shhh. I need to concentrate on the blockbuster if I'm gonna destroy it.

turns.speaker: LENNY
turns.text: Destroy it?

turns.speaker: EVAN
turns.text: If I hadn't blown my arms off, Mom never woulda started smoking in the first place. Now shhhh.

turns.speaker: EVAN
turns.text: Hey, what'd you do that for?

turns.speaker: TOMMY
turns.text: Fat little baby, crying for mommy.

turns.speaker: EVAN
turns.text: Tommy, I'm bored shitless over here. What's up already?

turns.speaker: TOMMY
turns.text: Hold your horses, man. It's here somewhere. I saw it when I was a kid.

turns.speaker: TOMMY
turns.text: Hurry! Let's go! Get him up, Evan! Come on!

turns.speaker: EVAN
turns.text: What happened?? Where are we?!

turns.speaker: TOMMY
turns.text: Look what you made me do!

turns.speaker: EVAN
turns.text: What's wrong with you?!

turns.speaker: EVAN
turns.text: Leave us alone you sick fuck!

turns.speaker: TOMMY
turns.text: Get this "us" shit. As if I was gonna lay a hand on my own sister. You've done nicely for yourself, Evan. Nice friends, nice life, not to mention you're fucking my sister. Not a bad piece of ass if I say so myself.

turns.speaker: EVAN
turns.text: What the hell are you doing?

turns.speaker: TOMMY
turns.text: It wasn't enough that the whole world loves you, but you had to take away the last person on earth who didn't think I was a piece of shit.

turns.speaker: EVAN
turns.text: No one thinks you're a piece of shit, Tommy.

turns.speaker: TOMMY
turns.text: Right, Evan. I believe you just said "sick fuck."

turns.speaker: TOMMY
turns.text: Listen to me good, Evan...

turns.speaker: EVAN
turns.text: I'll do whatever you want. You don't want me to ever see Kayleigh again, fine. Just let Crockett go. Besides, you kill him now and they'll stick you in juvy for sure. And I know you'd never leave your sister alone with your father.

turns.speaker: TOMMY
turns.text: I did what you said, man! We're pooling our student funds with Hillel House and we're going to have an Awareness Dance.

turns.speaker: EVAN
turns.text: Oh goody, nothing like spinning my chair around to a techno mix of Hava Nagila til I puke.

turns.speaker: EVAN
turns.text: Lung cancer?

turns.speaker: TOMMY
turns.text: Sorry, Mrs. T. He's been out of sorts lately.

turns.speaker: EVAN
turns.text: Mom. Don't cry. I can change this.

turns.speaker: TOMMY
turns.text: I think I'll go check out the chapel.

turns.speaker: WAITRESS
turns.text: Just get out, didja?

turns.speaker: EVAN
turns.text: Huh?

turns.speaker: WAITRESS
turns.text: Nothing. Just that my brother did a stint in the pen and he used to eat like that.

turns.speaker: EVAN
turns.text: I come from a big family.

turns.speaker: WAITRESS
turns.text: Meant no offense.

turns.speaker: EVAN
turns.text: None taken. Hey, uh, does Kayleigh Miller still work here?

turns.speaker: WAITRESS
turns.text: Sorry. Never heard of her.

turns.speaker: KAYLEIGH
turns.text: Evan, guess what? Dad got a new video camera and we're all gonna be in a movie.

turns.speaker: TOMMY
turns.text: I don't think Evan gets to be in it --

turns.speaker: KAYLEIGH
turns.text: Quit it, Tommy. Evan gets to be Robin Hood. I'm gonna be Maid Marian, and you're the Sheriff of Nottingham!

turns.speaker: TOMMY
turns.text: I thought I was the bad guy!

turns.speaker: KAYLEIGH
turns.text: You are, silly. He's a bad sheriff.

turns.speaker: TOMMY
turns.text: What did I say about mentioning that bitch?

turns.speaker: KAYLEIGH
turns.text: Where the hell are you taking us anyway? Just blow something up already.

turns.speaker: TOMMY
turns.text: Just blow something up? Are you nuts? There's an art to mass destruction. Would you just paint the Mona Lisa? No. Besides, we're here already.

turns.speaker: TOMMY
turns.text: Wipe that sad-assed look off your face before you get us all busted. You see the way Evan's mom was looking at you?

turns.speaker: KAYLEIGH
turns.text: I'm sorry.

turns.speaker: TOMMY
turns.text: Lenny? Come on!

turns.speaker: KAYLEIGH
turns.text: Oh my God oh my God...

turns.speaker: KAYLEIGH
turns.text: Shut up, Tommy!

turns.speaker: TOMMY
turns.text: Aw, hey now, that was a compliment.

turns.speaker: LENNY
turns.text: You put the mommy too far away. Mrs. Boswell has macaroni and glue if you wanna fix it.

turns.speaker: TOMMY
turns.text: You're such a retard!

turns.speaker: TOMMY
turns.text: Here you go, buddy.

turns.speaker: LENNY
turns.text: What? No frigging way, man. I'm not touching that thing.

turns.speaker: TOMMY
turns.text: The hell you aren't. Anyone of us does it, you'll puss out and narc for sure.

turns.speaker: LENNY
turns.text: Ain't gonna work this time, buddy. Look how small that fuse is! I'll get killed.

turns.speaker: LENNY
turns.text: Maybe it went out. Should someone check it?

turns.speaker: TOMMY
turns.text: Yeah, you do that, Lenny.

turns.speaker: ANNINA
turns.text: Monsieur Rick?

turns.speaker: RICK
turns.text: Yes?

turns.speaker: ANNINA
turns.text: Could I speak to you for just a moment, please?

turns.speaker: RICK
turns.text: How did you get in here? You're under age.

turns.speaker: ANNINA
turns.text: I came with Captain Renault.

turns.speaker: RICK
turns.text: I should have known.

turns.speaker: ANNINA
turns.text: My husband is with me, too.

turns.speaker: RICK
turns.text: He is? Well, Captain Renault's getting broadminded. Sit down. Will you have a drink?

turns.speaker: RICK
turns.text: No, of course not. Do you mind if I do?

turns.speaker: ANNINA
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: ANNINA
turns.text: Monsieur Rick, what kind of man is Captain Renault?

turns.speaker: RICK
turns.text: Oh, he's just like any other man, only more so.

turns.speaker: ANNINA
turns.text: No, I mean, is he trustworthy? Is his word --

turns.speaker: RICK
turns.text: -- Now, just a minute. Who told you to ask me that?

turns.speaker: ANNINA
turns.text: He did. Captain Renault did.

turns.speaker: RICK
turns.text: I thought so. Where's your husband?

turns.speaker: ANNINA
turns.text: At the roulette table, trying to win enough for our exit visa. Well of course, he's losing.

turns.speaker: RICK
turns.text: How long have you been married?

turns.speaker: ANNINA
turns.text: Eight weeks. We come from Bulgaria. Oh, things are very bad there, Monsieur. A devil has the people by the throat. So, Jan and I, we, we do not want our children to grow up in such a country.

turns.speaker: RICK
turns.text: So you decided to go to America.

turns.speaker: ANNINA
turns.text: Yes, but we have not much money, and traveling is so expensive and difficult. It was much more than we thought to get here. And then Captain Renault sees us and he is so kind. He wants to help us.

turns.speaker: RICK
turns.text: Yes, I'll bet.

turns.speaker: ANNINA
turns.text: He tells me he can give us an exit visa, but we have no money.

turns.speaker: RICK
turns.text: Does he know that?

turns.speaker: ANNINA
turns.text: Oh, yes.

turns.speaker: RICK
turns.text: And he is still willing to give you a visa?

turns.speaker: ANNINA
turns.text: Yes, Monsieur.

turns.speaker: RICK
turns.text: And you want to know --

turns.speaker: ANNINA
turns.text: -- Will he keep his word?

turns.speaker: RICK
turns.text: He always has.

turns.speaker: RICK
turns.text: Nobody ever loved me that much.

turns.speaker: ANNINA
turns.text: And he never knew, and the girl kept this bad thing locked in her heart? That would be all right, wouldn't it?

turns.speaker: RICK
turns.text: You want my advice?

turns.speaker: ANNINA
turns.text: Oh, yes, please.

turns.speaker: RICK
turns.text: Go back to Bulgaria.

turns.speaker: ANNINA
turns.text: Oh, but if you knew what it means to us to leave Europe, to get to America! Oh, but if Jan should find out! He is such a boy. In many ways I am so much older than he is.

turns.speaker: RICK
turns.text: Yes, well, everybody in Casablanca has problems. Yours may work out. You'll excuse me.

turns.speaker: ANNINA
turns.text: Monsieur Rick, I --

turns.speaker: RICK
turns.text: -- He's just a lucky guy.

turns.speaker: BERGER
turns.text: Excuse me, but you look like a couple who are on their way to America.

turns.speaker: LASZLO
turns.text: Well?

turns.speaker: BERGER
turns.text: You will find a market there for this ring. I am forced to sell it at a great sacrifice.

turns.speaker: LASZLO
turns.text: Thank you, but I hardly think --

turns.speaker: BERGER
turns.text: -- Then perhaps for the lady. The ring is quite unique.

turns.speaker: BERGER
turns.text: Good.

turns.speaker: LASZLO
turns.text: What is your name?

turns.speaker: BERGER
turns.text: Berger, Norwegian, and at your service, sir.

turns.speaker: BERGER
turns.text: Such a bargain. But that is your decision?

turns.speaker: LASZLO
turns.text: I'm sorry. It is.

turns.speaker: LASZLO
turns.text: Mr. Berger, the ring, could I see it again?

turns.speaker: BERGER
turns.text: Yes, Monsieur.

turns.speaker: LASZLO
turns.text: A champagne cocktail, please.

turns.speaker: BERGER
turns.text: I recognize you from the news photographs, Monsieur Laszlo.

turns.speaker: LASZLO
turns.text: In a concentration camp, one is apt to lose a little weight.

turns.speaker: BERGER
turns.text: We read five times that you were killed in five different places.

turns.speaker: LASZLO
turns.text: As you see, it was true every single time. Thank heaven I found you, Berger. I am looking for a man by the name of Ugarte. He is supposed to help me.

turns.speaker: LASZLO
turns.text: I see.

turns.speaker: BERGER
turns.text: But we who are still free will do all we can. We are organized, Monsieur, underground like everywhere else. Tomorrow night there is a meeting at the Caverne du Bois. If you would come...

turns.speaker: CARL
turns.text: Monsieur Rick, may I get you a cup of coffee?

turns.speaker: RICK
turns.text: No thanks, Carl.

turns.speaker: CARL
turns.text: Monsieur Rick!

turns.speaker: CARL
turns.text: Well, you are in pretty good shape, Herr Rick.

turns.speaker: RICK
turns.text: How long can I afford to stay closed?

turns.speaker: CARL
turns.text: Oh, two weeks, maybe three.

turns.speaker: RICK
turns.text: Maybe I won't have to. A bribe has worked before. In the meantime, everybody stays on salary.

turns.speaker: CARL
turns.text: Oh, thank you, Herr Rick. Sacha will be happy to hear it. I owe him money.

turns.speaker: RICK
turns.text: Now you finish locking up, will you, Carl?

turns.speaker: CARL
turns.text: I will. Then I am going to the meeting of the --

turns.speaker: RICK
turns.text: -- Don't tell me where you're going.

turns.speaker: CARL
turns.text: I won't.

turns.speaker: RICK
turns.text: Goodnight.

turns.speaker: CARL
turns.text: Goodnight, Monsieur Rick.

turns.speaker: CARL
turns.text: The police break up our meeting. Herr Rick! We escaped in the last moment.

turns.speaker: RICK
turns.text: Come up here a minute.

turns.speaker: CARL
turns.text: Yes, I come.

turns.speaker: RICK
turns.text: I want you to turn out the light in the rear entrance. It might attract the police.

turns.speaker: CARL
turns.text: But Sacha always puts out that light --

turns.speaker: RICK
turns.text: -- Tonight he forgot.

turns.speaker: CARL
turns.text: Yes, I come, I will do it.

turns.speaker: RICK
turns.text: I want you to take Miss Lund home.

turns.speaker: CARL
turns.text: Yes, sir.

turns.speaker: EMIL
turns.text: Excuse me, Monsieur Rick, but a gentleman inside has won twenty thousand francs. The cashier would like some money.

turns.speaker: RICK
turns.text: Well, I'll get it from the safe.

turns.speaker: EMIL
turns.text: I am so upset, Monsieur Rick. You know I can't understand --

turns.speaker: RICK
turns.text: -- Forget it, Emil. Mistakes like that happen all the time.

turns.speaker: EMIL
turns.text: I'm awfully sorry.

turns.speaker: RICK
turns.text: Here you are.

turns.speaker: EMIL
turns.text: It shall not happen again, Monsieur.

turns.speaker: RICK
turns.text: That's all right.

turns.speaker: EUROPEAN
turns.text: Here's to you, sir.

turns.speaker: TOURIST
turns.text: Er, good luck, yes.

turns.speaker: EUROPEAN
turns.text: I'd better be going.

turns.speaker: TOURIST
turns.text: Er, my check, please.

turns.speaker: EUROPEAN
turns.text: I have to warn you, sir. I beseech you...

turns.speaker: TOURIST
turns.text: Er, goodbye, sir.

turns.speaker: EUROPEAN
turns.text: It has been a pleasure to meet you.

turns.speaker: FERRARI
turns.text: Hello, Rick.

turns.speaker: RICK
turns.text: Hello, Ferrari. How's business at the Blue Parrot?

turns.speaker: FERRARI
turns.text: Fine, but I would like to buy your cafe.

turns.speaker: RICK
turns.text: It's not for sale.

turns.speaker: FERRARI
turns.text: You haven't heard my offer.

turns.speaker: RICK
turns.text: It's not for sale at any price.

turns.speaker: FERRARI
turns.text: What do you want for Sam?

turns.speaker: RICK
turns.text: I don't buy or sell human beings.

turns.speaker: FERRARI
turns.text: That's too bad. That's Casablanca's leading commodity. In refugees alone we could make a fortune if you would work with me through the black market.

turns.speaker: RICK
turns.text: Suppose you run your business and let me run mine.

turns.speaker: FERRARI
turns.text: Suppose we ask Sam. Maybe he'd like to make a change.

turns.speaker: RICK
turns.text: Suppose we do.

turns.speaker: FERRARI
turns.text: My dear Rick, when will you realize that in this world today isolationism is no longer a practical policy?

turns.speaker: RICK
turns.text: I see the bus is in. I'll take my shipment with me.

turns.speaker: FERRARI
turns.text: No hurry. I'll have it sent over. Have a drink with me.

turns.speaker: RICK
turns.text: I never drink in the morning. And every time you send my shipment over, it's always just a little bit short.

turns.speaker: FERRARI
turns.text: Carrying charges, my boy, carrying charges. Here, sit down. There's something I want to talk over with you, anyhow.

turns.speaker: FERRARI
turns.text: The bourbon.  The news about Ugarte upset me very much.

turns.speaker: RICK
turns.text: You're a fat hypocrite. You don't feel any sorrier for Ugarte than I do.

turns.speaker: FERRARI
turns.text: Of course not. What upsets me is the fact that Ugarte is dead and no one knows where those letters of transit are.

turns.speaker: RICK
turns.text: Practically no one.

turns.speaker: FERRARI
turns.text: If I could lay my hands on those letters, I could make a fortune.

turns.speaker: RICK
turns.text: So could I. And I'm a poor businessman.

turns.speaker: FERRARI
turns.text: I have a proposition for whoever has those letters. I will handle the entire transaction, get rid of the letters, take all the risk, for a small percentage.

turns.speaker: RICK
turns.text: And the carrying charges?

turns.speaker: FERRARI
turns.text: Naturally there will be a few incidental expenses. That is the proposition I have for whoever has those letters.

turns.speaker: RICK
turns.text: I'll tell him when he comes in.

turns.speaker: FERRARI
turns.text: Rick, I'll put my cards on the table. I think you know where those letters are.

turns.speaker: RICK
turns.text: Well, you're in good company. Renault and Strasser probably think so, too.

turns.speaker: RICK
turns.text: That's why I came over here to give them a chance to ransack my place.

turns.speaker: FERRARI
turns.text: Rick, don't be a fool. Take me into your confidence. You need a partner.

turns.speaker: FERRARI
turns.text: Shall we draw up the papers, or is our handshake good enough?

turns.speaker: RICK
turns.text: It's certainly not good enough. But since I'm in a hurry, it'll have to do.

turns.speaker: FERRARI
turns.text: Ah, to get out of Casablanca and go to America! You're a lucky man.

turns.speaker: RICK
turns.text: Oh, by the way, my agreement with Sam's always been that he gets twenty- five percent of the profits. That still goes.

turns.speaker: FERRARI
turns.text: Hmmm. I happen to know that he gets ten percent. But he's worth twenty- five.

turns.speaker: RICK
turns.text: And Abdul and Carl and Sacha, they stay with the place, or I don't sell.

turns.speaker: FERRARI
turns.text: Of course they stay. Rick's wouldn't be Rick's without them.

turns.speaker: RICK
turns.text: Well, so long.

turns.speaker: RICK
turns.text: Don't forget, you owe Rick's a hundred cartons of American cigarettes.

turns.speaker: FERRARI
turns.text: I shall remember to pay it... to myself.

turns.speaker: LASZLO
turns.text: You see, my dear, the word has gone around.

turns.speaker: FERRARI
turns.text: As leader of all illegal activities in Casablanca, I am an influential and respected man. It would not be worth my life to do anything for Monsieur Laszlo. You, however, are a different matter.

turns.speaker: LASZLO
turns.text: Signor Ferrari thinks it might just be possible to get an exit visa for you.

turns.speaker: LASZLO
turns.text: I will stay here and keep on trying. I'm sure in a little while --

turns.speaker: FERRARI
turns.text: -- We might as well be frank, Monsieur. It will take a miracle to get you out of Casablanca. And the Germans have outlawed miracles.

turns.speaker: LASZLO
turns.text: We've decided, Signor Ferrari. For the present we'll go on looking for two exit visas. Thank you very much.

turns.speaker: FERRARI
turns.text: Well, good luck. But be careful.  You know you're being shadowed?

turns.speaker: FERRARI
turns.text: I observe that you in one respect are a very fortunate man, Monsieur. I am moved to make one more suggestion, why, I do not know, because it cannot possibly profit me, but, have you heard about Signor Ugarte and the letters of transit?

turns.speaker: LASZLO
turns.text: Yes, something.

turns.speaker: FERRARI
turns.text: Those letters were not found on Ugarte when they arrested him.

turns.speaker: LASZLO
turns.text: Do you know where they are?

turns.speaker: FERRARI
turns.text: Not for sure, Monsieur, but I will venture to guess that Ugarte left those letters with Monsieur Rick.

turns.speaker: LASZLO
turns.text: Rick?

turns.speaker: FERRARI
turns.text: He is a difficult customer, that Rick. One never knows what he'll do or why. But it is worth a chance.

turns.speaker: LASZLO
turns.text: Thank you very much. Good day.

turns.speaker: FERRARI
turns.text: It was gracious of you to share it with me. Good day, Mademoiselle, Monsieur.

turns.speaker: LASZLO
turns.text: Good day.

turns.speaker: STRASSER
turns.text: And Mademoiselle?

turns.speaker: ILSA
turns.text: You needn't be concerned about me.

turns.speaker: STRASSER
turns.text: Mademoiselle, after this disturbance it is not safe for Laszlo to stay in Casablanca.

turns.speaker: ILSA
turns.text: This morning you implied it was not safe for him to leave Casablanca.

turns.speaker: STRASSER
turns.text: That is also true, except for one destination, to return to occupied France.

turns.speaker: ILSA
turns.text: Occupied France?

turns.speaker: STRASSER
turns.text: Uh huh. Under a safe conduct from me.

turns.speaker: ILSA
turns.text: What value is that? You may recall what German guarantees have been worth in the past.

turns.speaker: STRASSER
turns.text: There are only two other alternatives for him.

turns.speaker: ILSA
turns.text: What are they?

turns.speaker: STRASSER
turns.text: It is possible the French authorities will find a reason to put him in the concentration camp here.

turns.speaker: ILSA
turns.text: And the other alternative?

turns.speaker: STRASSER
turns.text: My dear Mademoiselle, perhaps you have already observed that in Casablanca, human life is cheap. Good night, Mademoiselle.

turns.speaker: RICK
turns.text: -- It was "La Belle Aurore."

turns.speaker: ILSA
turns.text: How nice. You remembered. But of course, that was the day the Germans marched into Paris.

turns.speaker: RICK
turns.text: Not an easy day to forget.

turns.speaker: ILSA
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: RICK
turns.text: I remember every detail. The Germans wore gray, you wore blue.

turns.speaker: ILSA
turns.text: Yes. I put that dress away. When the Germans march out, I'll wear it again.

turns.speaker: ILSA
turns.text: Say goodnight to Sam for me.

turns.speaker: RICK
turns.text: I will.

turns.speaker: ILSA
turns.text: There's still nobody in the world who can play "As Time Goes By" like Sam.

turns.speaker: RICK
turns.text: He hasn't played it in a long time.

turns.speaker: RICK
turns.text: Who are you really? And what were you before? What did you do and what did you think? Huh?

turns.speaker: ILSA
turns.text: We said "no questions."

turns.speaker: RICK
turns.text: Here's looking at you, kid.

turns.speaker: ILSA
turns.text: A franc for your thoughts.

turns.speaker: RICK
turns.text: In America they'd bring only a penny. I guess that's about all they're worth.

turns.speaker: ILSA
turns.text: I'm willing to be overcharged. Tell me.

turns.speaker: RICK
turns.text: And I was wondering.

turns.speaker: ILSA
turns.text: Yes?

turns.speaker: RICK
turns.text: Why I'm so lucky. Why I should find you waiting for me to come along.

turns.speaker: ILSA
turns.text: Why there is no other man in my life?

turns.speaker: RICK
turns.text: Uh huh.

turns.speaker: ILSA
turns.text: That's easy. There was. He's dead.

turns.speaker: RICK
turns.text: I'm sorry for asking. I forgot we said "no questions."

turns.speaker: ILSA
turns.text: Well, only one answer can take care of all our questions.

turns.speaker: ILSA
turns.text: Richard, they'll find out your record. It won't be safe for you here.

turns.speaker: RICK
turns.text: I'm on their blacklist already, their roll of honor.

turns.speaker: RICK
turns.text: My German's a little rusty.

turns.speaker: ILSA
turns.text: It's the Gestapo. They say they expect to be in Paris tomorrow.

turns.speaker: ILSA
turns.text: With the whole world crumbling, we pick this time to fall in love.

turns.speaker: RICK
turns.text: Yeah. It's pretty bad timing. Where were you, say, ten years ago?

turns.speaker: ILSA
turns.text: Ten years ago? Let's see...  ...Yes. I was having a brace put on my teeth. Where were you?

turns.speaker: RICK
turns.text: Looking for a job.

turns.speaker: ILSA
turns.text: Was that cannon fire, or is it my heart pounding?

turns.speaker: RICK
turns.text: Ah, that's the new German 77. And judging by the sound, only about thirty-five miles away.

turns.speaker: ILSA
turns.text: Strange. I know so very little about you.

turns.speaker: RICK
turns.text: I know very little about you, just the fact that you had your teeth straightened.

turns.speaker: ILSA
turns.text: But be serious, darling. You are in danger and you must leave Paris.

turns.speaker: RICK
turns.text: No, no, no, no. We must leave.

turns.speaker: ILSA
turns.text: Yes, of course, we --

turns.speaker: RICK
turns.text: -- The train for Marseilles leaves at five o'clock. I'll pick you up at your hotel at four-thirty.

turns.speaker: ILSA
turns.text: No, no. Not at my hotel. I, uh, I have things to do in the city before I leave. I'll meet you at the station, huh?

turns.speaker: RICK
turns.text: All right. At a quarter to five.  Say, why don't we get married in Marseilles?

turns.speaker: ILSA
turns.text: That's too far ahead to plan.

turns.speaker: RICK
turns.text: Yes, I guess it is a little too far ahead. Well, let's see. What about the engineer? Why can't he marry us on the train?

turns.speaker: ILSA
turns.text: Oh, darling!

turns.speaker: RICK
turns.text: Well, why not? The captain on a ship can. It doesn't seem fair that... Hey, hey, what's wrong, kid?

turns.speaker: ILSA
turns.text: I love you so much, and I hate this war so much. Oh, it's a crazy world. Anything can happen. If you shouldn't get away, I mean, if, if something should keep us apart, wherever they put you and wherever I'll be, I want you to know...

turns.speaker: RICK
turns.text: Oh. I saved my first drink to have with you. Here.

turns.speaker: ILSA
turns.text: No. No, Rick. Not tonight.

turns.speaker: RICK
turns.text: Especially tonight.

turns.speaker: ILSA
turns.text: Please.

turns.speaker: RICK
turns.text: Why did you have to come to Casablanca? There are other places.

turns.speaker: ILSA
turns.text: I wouldn't have come if I had known that you were here. Believe me, Rick, it's true. I didn't know.

turns.speaker: RICK
turns.text: It's funny about your voice, how it hasn't changed. I can still hear it. "Richard dear, I'll go with you any place. We'll get on a train together and never stop."

turns.speaker: ILSA
turns.text: Please don't. Don't, Rick. I can understand how you feel.

turns.speaker: RICK
turns.text: Huh! You understand how I feel. How long was it we had, honey?

turns.speaker: ILSA
turns.text: I didn't count the days.

turns.speaker: RICK
turns.text: Well, I did. Every one of them. Mostly I remember the last one. A wow finish. A guy standing on a station platform in the rain with a comical look on his face, because his insides had been kicked out.

turns.speaker: ILSA
turns.text: Can I tell you a story, Rick?

turns.speaker: RICK
turns.text: Has it got a wow finish?

turns.speaker: ILSA
turns.text: I don't know the finish yet.

turns.speaker: RICK
turns.text: Well, go on, tell it. Maybe one will come to you as you go along.

turns.speaker: ILSA
turns.text: It's about a girl who had just come to Paris from her home in Oslo. At the house of some friends she met a man about whom she'd heard her whole life, a very great and courageous man. He opened up for her a whole beautiful world full of knowledge and thoughts and ideals. Everything she knew or ever became was because of him. And she looked up to him and worshipped him with a feeling she supposed was love.

turns.speaker: RICK
turns.text: Yes, that's very pretty. I heard a story once. As a matter of fact, I've heard a lot of stories in my time. They went along with the sound of a tinny piano playing in the parlor downstairs, "Mister, I met a man once when I was a kid," it'd always begin. Huh. I guess neither one of our stories was very funny. Tell me, who was it you left me for? Was it Laszlo, or were there others in between? Or aren't you the kind that tells?

turns.speaker: RICK
turns.text: I'm sorry I was in no condition to receive you when you called on me last night.

turns.speaker: ILSA
turns.text: It doesn't matter.

turns.speaker: RICK
turns.text: Why did you come back? To tell me why you ran out on me at the railway station?

turns.speaker: ILSA
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: RICK
turns.text: Well, you can tell me now. I'm reasonably sober.

turns.speaker: ILSA
turns.text: I don't think I will, Rick.

turns.speaker: RICK
turns.text: Why not? After all, I got stuck with a railway ticket. I think I'm entitled to know.

turns.speaker: ILSA
turns.text: Last night I saw what has happened to you. The Rick I knew in Paris, I could tell him. He'd understand. But the one who looked at me with such hatred... well, I'll be leaving Casablanca soon and we'll never see each other again. We knew very little about each other when we were in love in Paris. If we leave it that way, maybe we'll remember those days and not Casablanca, not last night.

turns.speaker: RICK
turns.text: Did you run out on me because you couldn't take it? Because you knew what it would be like, hiding from the police, running away all the time?

turns.speaker: ILSA
turns.text: You can believe that if you want to.

turns.speaker: RICK
turns.text: Well, I'm not running away any more. I'm settled now, above a saloon, it's true, but... walk up a flight. I'll be expecting you.

turns.speaker: RICK
turns.text: All the same, someday you'll lie to Laszlo. You'll be there.

turns.speaker: ILSA
turns.text: No, Rick. No, you see, Victor Laszlo is my husband... and was, even when I knew you in Paris.

turns.speaker: RICK
turns.text: How did you get in?

turns.speaker: ILSA
turns.text: The stairs from the street.

turns.speaker: RICK
turns.text: I told you this morning you'd come around, but this is a little ahead of schedule. Well, won't you sit down?

turns.speaker: ILSA
turns.text: Richard, I had to see you.

turns.speaker: RICK
turns.text: You use "Richard" again? We're back in Paris.

turns.speaker: ILSA
turns.text: Please.

turns.speaker: RICK
turns.text: Your unexpected visit isn't connected by any chance with the letters of transit? It seems that as long as I have those letters I'll never be lonely.

turns.speaker: ILSA
turns.text: You can ask any price you want, but you must give me those letters.

turns.speaker: RICK
turns.text: I went through all that with your husband. It's no deal.

turns.speaker: ILSA
turns.text: I know how you feel about me, but I'm asking you to put your feelings aside for something more important.

turns.speaker: RICK
turns.text: Do I have to hear again what a great man your husband is? What an important cause he's fighting for?

turns.speaker: ILSA
turns.text: It was your cause, too. In your own way, you were fighting for the same thing.

turns.speaker: RICK
turns.text: I'm not fighting for anything anymore, except myself. I'm the only cause I'm interested in.

turns.speaker: ILSA
turns.text: Richard, Richard, we loved each other once. If those days meant anything at all to you --

turns.speaker: RICK
turns.text: -- I wouldn't bring up Paris if I were you. It's poor salesmanship.

turns.speaker: ILSA
turns.text: Please. Please listen to me. If you knew what really happened, if you only knew the truth --

turns.speaker: RICK
turns.text: -- I wouldn't believe you, no matter what you told me. You'd say anything now to get what you want.

turns.speaker: ILSA
turns.text: No. Oh, Richard, I'm sorry. I'm sorry, but, but you, you are our last hope. If you don't help us, Victor Laszlo will die in Casablanca.

turns.speaker: RICK
turns.text: What of it? I'm going to die in Casablanca. It's a good spot for it.

turns.speaker: ILSA
turns.text: -- All right. I tried to reason with you. I tried everything. Now I want those letters. Get them for me.

turns.speaker: RICK
turns.text: I don't have to. I've got them right here.

turns.speaker: ILSA
turns.text: Put them on the table.

turns.speaker: RICK
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: ILSA
turns.text: For the last time, put them on the table.

turns.speaker: RICK
turns.text: If Laszlo and the cause mean so much to you, you won't stop at anything. All right, I'll make it easier for you.

turns.speaker: RICK
turns.text: And then?

turns.speaker: ILSA
turns.text: It wasn't long after we were married that Victor went back to Czechoslovakia. They needed him in Prague, but there the Gestapo were waiting for him. Just a two-line item in the paper: "Victor Laszlo apprehended. Sent to concentration camp." I was frantic. For months I tried to get word. Then it came. He was dead, shot trying to escape. I was lonely. I had nothing. Not even hope. Then I met you.

turns.speaker: RICK
turns.text: Why weren't you honest with me? Why did you keep your marriage a secret?

turns.speaker: ILSA
turns.text: Oh, it wasn't my secret, Richard. Victor wanted it that way. Not even our closest friends knew about our marriage. That was his way of protecting me. I knew so much about his work, and if the Gestapo found out I was his wife it would be dangerous for me and for those working with me.

turns.speaker: RICK
turns.text: When did you first find out he was alive?

turns.speaker: ILSA
turns.text: Just before you and I were to leave Paris together. A friend came and told me that Victor was alive. They were hiding him in a freight car on the outskirts of Paris. He was sick, he needed me. I wanted to tell you, but I, I didn't care. I knew, I knew you wouldn't have left Paris, and the Gestapo would have caught you. So I... well, well, you know the rest.

turns.speaker: RICK
turns.text: Huh. But it's still a story without an ending. What about now?

turns.speaker: ILSA
turns.text: Now? I don't know. I know that I'll never have the strength to leave you again.

turns.speaker: RICK
turns.text: And Laszlo?

turns.speaker: ILSA
turns.text: Oh, you'll help him now, Richard, won't you? You'll see that he gets out? Then he'll have his work, all that he's been living for.

turns.speaker: RICK
turns.text: All except one. He won't have you.

turns.speaker: ILSA
turns.text: I can't fight it anymore. I ran away from you once. I can't do it again. Oh, I don't know what's right any longer. You'll have to think for both of us, for all of us.

turns.speaker: RICK
turns.text: All right, I will. Here's looking at you, kid.

turns.speaker: ILSA
turns.text: I wish I didn't love you so much.

turns.speaker: ILSA
turns.text: Richard, Victor thinks I'm leaving with him. Haven't you told him?

turns.speaker: RICK
turns.text: No, not yet.

turns.speaker: ILSA
turns.text: But it's all right, isn't it? You were able to arrange everything?

turns.speaker: RICK
turns.text: Everything is quite all right.

turns.speaker: ILSA
turns.text: Oh, Rick!

turns.speaker: ILSA
turns.text: But why my name, Richard?

turns.speaker: RICK
turns.text: Because you're getting on that plane.

turns.speaker: ILSA
turns.text: I don't understand. What about you?

turns.speaker: RICK
turns.text: I'm staying here with him 'til the plane gets safely away.

turns.speaker: ILSA
turns.text: No, Richard, no. What has happened to you? Last night we said --

turns.speaker: RICK
turns.text: -- Last night we said a great many things. You said I was to do the thinking for both of us. Well, I've done a lot of it since then and it all adds up to one thing. You're getting on that plane with Victor where you belong.

turns.speaker: ILSA
turns.text: But Richard, no, I, I --

turns.speaker: RICK
turns.text: -- You've got to listen to me. Do you have any idea what you'd have to look forward to if you stayed here? Nine chances out of ten we'd both wind up in a concentration camp. Isn't that true, Louis?

turns.speaker: RICK
turns.text: I'm saying it because it's true. Inside of us we both know you belong with Victor. You're part of his work, the thing that keeps him going. If that plane leaves the ground and you're not with him, you'll regret it.

turns.speaker: ILSA
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: RICK
turns.text: Maybe not today, maybe not tomorrow, but soon, and for the rest of your life.

turns.speaker: ILSA
turns.text: But what about us?

turns.speaker: RICK
turns.text: We'll always have Paris. We didn't have, we'd lost it, until you came to Casablanca. We got it back last night.

turns.speaker: ILSA
turns.text: And I said I would never leave you.

turns.speaker: RICK
turns.text: And you never will. But I've got a job to do, too. Where I'm going you can't follow. What I've got to do you can't be any part of. Ilsa, I'm no good at being noble, but it doesn't take much to see that the problems of three little people don't amount to a hill of beans in this crazy world. Someday you'll understand that. Now, now...

turns.speaker: ILSA
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: RICK
turns.text: She tried everything to get them, and nothing worked. She did her best to convince me that she was still in love with me, but that was all over long ago. For your sake, she pretended it wasn't, and I let her pretend.

turns.speaker: ILSA
turns.text: Hello, Sam.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Hello, Miss Ilsa. I never expected to see you again.

turns.speaker: ILSA
turns.text: It's been a long time.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Yes, ma'am. A lot of water under the bridge.

turns.speaker: ILSA
turns.text: Some of the old songs, Sam.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Yes, ma'am.

turns.speaker: ILSA
turns.text: Where is Rick?

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: I don't know. I ain't seen him all night.

turns.speaker: ILSA
turns.text: When will he be back?

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Not tonight no more. He ain't coming. Uh, he went home.

turns.speaker: ILSA
turns.text: Does he always leave so early?

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Oh, he never... well...  he's got a girl up at the Blue Parrot. He goes up there all the time.

turns.speaker: ILSA
turns.text: You used to be a much better liar, Sam.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Leave him alone, Miss Ilsa. You're bad luck to him.

turns.speaker: ILSA
turns.text: Play it once, Sam, for old time's sake.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: I don't know what you mean, Miss Ilsa.

turns.speaker: ILSA
turns.text: Play it, Sam. Play "As Time Goes By."

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Oh I can't remember it, Miss Ilsa. I'm a little rusty on it.

turns.speaker: ILSA
turns.text: Victor, I, I feel somehow we shouldn't stay here.

turns.speaker: LASZLO
turns.text: If we would walk out so soon, it would only call attention to us. Perhaps Ugarte's in some other part of the cafe.

turns.speaker: ILSA
turns.text: You are very kind.

turns.speaker: LASZLO
turns.text: Won't you join us?

turns.speaker: LASZLO
turns.text: This time they really mean to stop me.

turns.speaker: ILSA
turns.text: Victor, I'm afraid for you.

turns.speaker: LASZLO
turns.text: We have been in difficult places before, haven't we?

turns.speaker: LASZLO
turns.text: I must find out what Berger knows.

turns.speaker: ILSA
turns.text: Be careful.

turns.speaker: LASZLO
turns.text: I will, don't worry.
